fdd:identificationAndDescription.fdd:description: Compressed FLAC data encapsulated in an Ogg transport layer, which helps overcome certain shortcomings of the transport system elements included in the "native FLAC" format. These native elements do not comprise a transport layer in terms of standard codec design; the transport cannot be entirely separated from the payload, and this approach does not support more elaborate transport mechanisms such as multiple logical streams.
fdd:identificationAndDescription.fdd:shortDescription: Compressed FLAC data encapsulated in an Ogg transport layer,which helps overcome certain shortcomings of the transport system elements included in the "native FLAC" format.
fdd:identificationAndDescription.fdd:productionPhase: Generally used for final-state, end-user delivery.

fdd:localUse.fdd:preference: WAVE_LCPM preferred for master copies of waveform sound.

fdd:notes.fdd:general:
Regarding file type signifiers, https://xiph.org/flac/ogg_mapping.html reports that Version 1.0 of the FLAC-to-Ogg mapping is a simple identifying header followed by pure native FLAC data. The first packet of a stream consists of:
The one-byte packet type 0x7F
The four-byte ASCII signature "FLAC", i.e. 0x46, 0x4C, 0x41, 0x43
A one-byte binary major version number for the mapping, e.g. 0x01 for mapping version 1.0
A one-byte binary minor version number for the mapping, e.g. 0x00 for mapping version 1.0
A two-byte, big-endian binary number signifying the number of header (non-audio) packets, not including this one. This number may be zero (0x0000) to signify 'unknown' but be aware that some decoders may not be able to handle such streams.
The four-byte ASCII native FLAC signature "fLaC" according to the FLAC format specification
